episode_summary: This episode features a variety of quirky and fascinating facts, including stories about self-experimentation, unusual survival techniques, and bizarre historical anecdotes. The hosts also discuss unique cultural practices, strange competitions, and humorous misunderstandings across languages.

facts.fact: Alain Bombard was a French doctor who shipwrecked himself to prove that one could survive without food or water by living off fish and plankton.
In 1920, a man named Arthur Cobcroft died from laughter after comparing commodity prices from 1915 to 1920 and finding the difference hilarious.
Bungay in East Anglia has the highest number of Satanists in the UK, according to a census.
In 1996, the Swedish Navy admitted that they had mistaken otters splashing for Russian submarines in their waters.
